title: Camden National Corp (CAC) Q1 2019 Earnings Call Transcript
callText:
Image source: The Motley Fool.

Camden National Corp  (NASDAQ:CAC)Q1 2019 Earnings CallApril 30, 2019, 1:00 p.m. ET
Contents:

Prepared Remarks
Questions and Answers
Call Participants

Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Good day, and welcome to the Camden National Corporation First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Chad, and I will be your operator for today's call. All participants will be in listen-only mode during today's presentation. Following the presentation we will conduct a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions).
Please note that this presentation contains forward-looking statements, which involve significant risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to vary materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in such forward-looking statements are described in the company's earnings press release, the company's 2018 annual report on Form 10-K and in other filings with the SEC.
The company does not undertake any obligation to update any forward-looking statements to reflect circumstances or events that occur after the forward-looking statements are made. Any references in today's presentation to non-GAAP financial measures are intended to provide meaningful insights and are reconciled with GAAP in your press release.
Today's call presenters are Greg Dufour, President, Chief Executive Officer and Director; and Deborah Jordan, Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer. Please also note that today's event is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Greg Dufour. Please go ahead, sir.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, and welcome to Camden National's first quarter earnings call. Earlier today we announced record quarterly earnings of $14.3 million or $0.91 per diluted share. I'm happy to share a few thoughts on the quarter to be followed by Debbie's review in the financial results.
First of all, we are thrilled to start of the year at such a strong note, continuing our momentum from the last quarter. We had really strong commercial loan closings in the first quarter, although total loan growth for the quarter was up slightly. This was due to increase prepayments we experienced driven by some of our commercial customers being acquired by other organizations and the lower interest rate environment driving refinancings.
One example, as we noted in this morning's earnings release was one commercial real estate customer refinanced $39.2 million of balances directly with the government-sponsored entity. We're still comfortable with our mid-single digital loan growth expectations and we are monitoring the environment very closely.
Secondly, our net interest margin of 3.18% for the first quarter 2019 remained relatively stable compared to the previous quarter supported by our investments in retail and commercial deposit gathering strategies and improving beneficial in the current interest rate environment. However, we remain cautious and are closely watching multiple loan and deposit pricing in our marketplaces.
Our 85% loan-to-deposit ratio places us in a strong position compared to other Northern New England Institutions. We understand that deposits are in a premium and the need to protect our deposits is critical as other organizations may need to rise -- raise deposits through increased pricing.
Finally, we continue to see strong asset quality as the markets we operate in remain stable. We have seen some narrowing of loan margins and changes in credit structure and feel we have the balance sheet position, margins and ability to analyze the risk and reward opportunities in the market.
In addition to a $0.30 per share dividend, which translates to a 2.88% dividend yield through the end of last week. We repurchased nearly 96,000 shares under our repurchase program that started in January, that average price was $41.87 per share.
To wrap up, we'll be holding our Annual Shareholder Meeting later this afternoon and we'll be posting material from that meeting to over Investor Relations website shortly. I'd like to now turn it over to Debbie to review the financials.
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
Thank you, Greg, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to report our first quarter results with quarterly net income of $14.3 million resulting in a return on average assets of 1.33% and a return on average tangible equity of 17.08% for the quarter.
Net income increased $296,000 or 2% compared to the previous quarter due to lower operating cost of $797,000 (ph) and growth in net interest income of $308,000, partially offset by an increase in the loan loss provision. Compared to the previous quarter, net interest income increased 1%, as this quarter benefited from a strong finish to last year with the surge in both loan and deposit growth. Average loan and deposit balances were each up 3% compared to a quarter ago.
When compared to the fourth quarter, our net interest margin declined three basis points this quarter as assets yields increased nine basis points while funding costs increased 13 basis points. While excluding fair value accretion, net interest margin was flat between periods at 3.14%.
Net interest margin was a little higher than anticipated in the first quarter as overnight borrowings were lower than usual this time of year due to our total deposit levels. Our loan portfolio increased $16.2 million since December 31st with just under a 1% growth rate.
Residential mortgages grew 2% between quarters with about a 50-50 mix of adjustable rate mortgages versus fixed rate jumbo mortgages. Commercial real estate balances declined 1% since year-end despite healthy loan origination volume as prepayments were almost double our normal rates. The larger commercial prepayments were anticipated and we expect to return to lower prepayment levels this quarter.
Total deposit grew $113.7 million or 3% between quarters. Interest checking balances were up $140 million since year-end, primarily due to larger commercial deposit relationships which included new funds as well as a shift from money markets to interest checking.
Broker deposit balances also increased during the quarter by $70.7 million as we used brokerage funds as an alternative to borrowing.
Total fee income declined $90,000 between quarters or a 1% change. Debit card income decreased $829,000 between periods due to the seasonal decline in activity, as well as receiving an annual VISA intensive bonus in the previous quarter. Partially offsetting the decline was an increase in back-to-back loan swap fee income of $124,000 as well as security losses of $420,000 recorded in the fourth quarter of last year.
As Greg mentioned, asset quality remained strong with annualized net charge-offs of three basis points of average loans for the quarter and a loan loss provision of $744,000 which translates to 10 basis points on average loans. The increase in provision expense between quarters was largely due to the favorable resolution of a commercial credit in the fourth quarter last year that freed up our reserve on this relationship.
Operating expenses decreased $797,000 between quarters primarily due to the change in total collection cost of $677,000 between periods as certain expenses recorded in the fourth quarter were fully recovered in the first quarter. And forecasting the remainder of 2019 we anticipate our efficiency ratio to range between 57% and 57. 5%. As we expect to see increased operating costs related to compensation occupancy and technology.
That concludes our comments on the first quarter results. We'll now open the call up for questions. Chad?
Questions and Answers:
Operator
Thank you. We will now begin the question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) The first question will come from Matthew Breese with Piper Jaffray. Please go ahead.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Good afternoon.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Hi, Matt.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Hi. I am -- sorry, I wanted to start on just get a little bit color on the net interest margin that came in very strong this quarter and maybe to kind of kick it off. In the release you do mention that you had some large commercial deposit relationships that showed a lot the commercial growth this quarter. You also note that it's subject to variability in balances. And so, as you looked at what came in this quarter, could you just give us some better color around the stickiness of the relationships that came in? And whether or not the margin was in any way artificially inflated this quarter due to that?
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
Yeah, Matt, and I'll be happy to answer that. Some of the funds that have actually already outflowed. Some have moved into CDs. And so that's why we highlighted it in our earnings releases, it is going to be more valuable than in the past. And so that certainly helped the margin a little bit. I think our -- we still have been fairly solid in managing the cost of funds so that increase just hasn't had -- has happened as fast. I do think in the second quarter when I look at our net interest margin we are going to see a trend down of two to three basis points in the second quarter.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Right. Okay. Two to three basis points in the second quarter. Now, as we think about the back half of the year that's typically when you start to see some inflows of lower costs and deposits and usually we see a little bit of a bump in the NIM.
Last quarter was -- I mean, last year it was -- I think may be eight, nine, 10 basis points. Could you just describe given the backdrop of where the Fed is now? How you expect at the back of the year NIM to kind of behave?
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
Sure. We're asset sensitive and so certainly with the rising rate environment we were having our asset yields on the loan side in particular repriced at a higher level. So we were lagging our increase in cost of funds and so we were getting that pickup in the net interest margin. Now that it looks like the Fed is on hold, we won't be getting that asset yields pickup and even a volume for the first quarter on the loan side went on at our portfolio yield. So we're not going to get any lift on the asset side. I think we are going to continue to see that cost of funds edge up a little bit and so when I take a step back and look for the remainder of the year. I think on average for the year we'll be at our current level. We rightly do have seasonality, so we'll bump down but then we'll have a pickup in NIM. But we will see our cost of funds rise a little bit.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Understood. Okay. If you could just give us some color on the loan growth and the competitive dynamics in your markets, how things have changed? And then give us a sense for this quarter's pipeline versus last quarter. That would be helpful.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Sure. And, let me start off by the competitive environment. And it really is just trending as we have seen it for the past couple of years. We have several strong good community bank competitors that are there getting into transactions they tend over the past couple of years tend to be upscaling the size deals that they will play in. Probably a bigger change is we're seeing more national players come in -- into the market. Wells Fargo has an office in Portland. JPMorgan Chase opened up a loan office in Portland as well. And they're starting to play in some of the deals probably the deals they play intend to be on our upper end obviously, but they are getting in there. So that makes as a pretty frothy market on the loan side.
On a pipeline perspective, we're seeing the pipeline come down but that's because we are running at pre-record levels for two quarters. So we do expect that to come down and that works into where we're comfortable with that mid-single-digit loan growth for the year.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Okay. My last one is, just in terms of M&A, potential M&A. I want to get a sense for how conversations are going if there are any conversations? What parts of your geography that could happen? I understand it's probably a little bit more limited in terms of potential partner candidates. But I just wanted to get a sense for any activity that you're seeing.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Sure. While we -- obviously, as you know, we don't really comment on anything that we're doing on the M&A front, but taking a step back looking at the market especially in the growth area or the target area that we have previously identified which is Southern Maine with Eastern Massachusetts and the like those players tend to be on the smaller side on the scale spectrum. But it's a pretty frothy market, especially if you're on the sell side. The good thing is that we're disciplined, we have spoken a lot to investors and understand the requirements on tangible book value earn back and our focus on that. And we feel that's a prudent way to in the long-term preserve our capital.
But as well on the other side, as we have shown as most recently in 2015, for the Bank of Maine acquisition, what's happened since then, we are very confident in our ability to execute on the transaction that we feel it's appropriate for us.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Understood. All right. That's all we had. Thanks for taking my questions.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Great. Thank you, Matt.
Operator
And our next question comes from Damon DelMonte with KBW. Please go ahead.
Damon DelMonte -- Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc -- Analyst
Hi, good afternoon, guys. How is it going today?
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Great, Dan. Thank you.
Damon DelMonte -- Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc -- Analyst
Great. Just on the -- first question I have is on expenses. I may have missed some of the guidance that Debbie had given. So I know that there was the kind of the reversal in the OREO line item. So if we kind of back that out and normalize that is something in that $23 million close to $23.5 million range for second quarter, is that a reasonable expectation?
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
No. I think it's going to run higher than that. In the last quarter I had said we expect to be around the $24 million mark on a quarterly basis going forward.
Damon DelMonte -- Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc -- Analyst
Okay. All right. Got it. Okay. That's helpful. And then on the fee income side, how are you looking at like mortgage banking going through the second and third quarters which typically are seasonally strong. I think, first quarter here was little bit better than what we've seen in the fourth quarter and you had some weakness due to seasonality in the first quarter. So how do you think the middle part of the year shaping up?
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
We look at it as it will be good. It remains to be seen how refinancing will go through that business at this point, because there has been just -- with the exception probably the past year, a lot of refinancing activity previous to that. From a new home perspective it's -- I would say, not as strong as in the peak of the market but we are seeing and we are hearing in reports that just the buying has still strong but tempered, I mean, it's not multiple offers coming in on homes that type of thing.
I think our benefit when we look at the mortgage business, isn't just the kind of the level of the market activity, but the fact that we're expanding into that business line. We have a good model, we can bring in strong mortgage, loan originators get them up to speed relatively quickly. And we have a great processing area that can execute on those transactions when they come in.
Damon DelMonte -- Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc -- Analyst
Got it. Okay. Okay. That's probably covers the thing what I had. Thank you very much. Appreciate the color.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Pleasure. Thank you, Damon.
Operator
(Operator Instructions) We have a follow-up question from Matthew Breese with Piper Jaffray. Please go ahead.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Me again. Just a couple of follow-ups, if you don't mind.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
No problem.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Just looking at your usage of capital, capital deployment, we saw a little bit of buyback this quarter. How are you thinking about using that lever? Do you think it will be more supplemental? Or are you driving to a capital target? Just help us learn a little bit more about that plan.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Yeah. Well, we're fortunate. We do have a capital committee of our board, which provides a lot of guidance and conversation that we have. And I think it's really just the guidance I'd give is really is block and tackling, do we feel that we have a use of capital. There is obviously the M&A question part of that, but it's also the loan growth question that we want to maintain adequate capital support that and we're fortunate that we have that. Once you get through that, then you get into, OK, what is the right color target levels. We really don't disclose what those target levels are, but we do look at ways that we can return capital when we don't feel we need it. And, I think if you look historically add us at our history that we do pretty well returning capital even through increasing dividends or repurchases like we're undergoing right now or even special dividends. And those are the discussions that we have in our board as we take that further future outlook.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Understood. And then just kind of following that line of questioning. How does the strategy on security portfolio fit in? And what should we expect there?
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
Yeah. We have a portfolio of a little over $900 million. We actually did a shift at the end of last year where we moved the bulk of our health maturity into the AFS category. One we had enough capital to absorb some of the volatility, but also want to have the flexibility if we decide to restructure the portfolio. We keep roughly 24% of investments in assets. In the past that's run higher, we continue to have conversations, do we deleverage a little bit on the balance sheet side? So we have a lot of flexibility on the investment side.
We structured it that, we have solid predictable cash flow coming of the investments, so we can either decide to reinvest or deleverage. One of the things that we're having a lot of conversations on is where do we think the rates are going in the long-term and do we -- is it time to start extending out on investments. So we're talking about that at the ALCO meeting at this point. So we will use the investment portfolio to help manage interest rate risk and we structured it to give us the greatest flexibility.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Okay. Understood. All right. And then last one just in regards to CECL. As I look at your reserve compared to a charge also historical charge-offs it seems like you have north of five years with the charges offs in your current reserve. So just thinking about where your first dates for preserve could go under CECL? Could you help us -- could you provide some color on what that could look like? And whether or not you're in a position to increase or even release a little bit of the reserve?
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Sure. Well we're not going to -- we're not ready yet or willing yet to give out any estimates what we expect the financial impact of CECL will be. But within CECL, I will say we have been focused on this for about three years. We've got a strong team working through this. And I know there is a lot of talk about potential postponements which from a industry perspective we support. Postponing it, because I think it's right for some, but we will be ready to go on 120.
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Got it. Okay. That's all we had. Thanks again.
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
Thanks, Matt.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Matt.
Operator
As we have no further questions, this concludes our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the conference back over to Greg Dufour for any closing remarks.
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, first of all, thank you all for taking the time to spend with us here on this earnings call and obviously review all the material that we're sending out. It really speaks to the engagement that we have from the analyst community, investor community, and our owners. That's really greatly appreciated with real that it's been a great quarter for us and we're looking forward to the meeting this afternoon with other shareholders. I wish everyone a great day.
Operator
Thank you. The conference has now concluded. Thank you for attending today's presentation. You may now disconnect your lines.
Duration: 23 minutes
Call participants:
Gregory A. Dufour -- President and Chief Executive Officer
Deborah A. Jordan -- Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer
Matthew Breese -- Piper Jaffray -- Analyst
Damon DelMonte -- Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods, Inc -- Analyst
More CAC analysis
